title-group.article-title: Development of a new finite element and parametric study for plates with compressible constrained layer damping

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Electromechanical Engineering, The University of Macau, Macau SAR, China
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Alabama, 290 Hardaway Hall, Box 870276, Tuscaloosa, AL 35487, USA

author-notes.corresp: Zhengchao Xie, Department of Electromechanical Engineering, The University of Macau, Macau SAR, China Email: zxie@umac.mo

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Constrained layer damping (CLD) is widely used in many structures for vibration reduction. It is necessary to model CLD structures precisely. Most existing research studies have modeled the structures as beams, which in many cases is not a sufficient approach. These existing models are based on the assumption that shear deformation in the core layer is the only source of damping in the structure. However, previous research has shown that other types of deformation in the core layer, such as deformations from longitudinal extension and transverse compression, can also be important. To more accurately model CLD, a new plate finite element is developed in this study by assuming that there is shear as well as longitudinal and transverse deformations in the damping layer. This model can be used to better predict the structure’s dynamic characteristics, such as resonant frequencies and modal loss factors. By comparing the new model to experimental results from the open literature, this newly developed plate finite element model is validated. With all three types of damping included in this new approach, it becomes possible to study the impact of various design parameters, such as the damping layer’s thickness. To that end, a parametric study is also conducted using the newly developed finite element for various design parameters.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Constrained layer damping (CLD) has been shown to be an effective approach for vibration control. The fundamental mechanism of CLD is that the relative motion of two face layers leads to the deformation of the damping layer; the energy consumed through the deformation of the damping layer results in the damping effect. Currently, relatively large damping ratios can be achieved through a wide range of available viscoelastic materials.

In previous research studies, extensive investigations have been conducted on modeling CLD for beam structures. These works have widely employed the assumption proposed by Ross et al.1 that only shear deformation (i.e., pure shear) occurs in the damping layer. Under this assumption, the two face layers are treated as Euler beams while the core layer only experiences shear deformation. The motions associated with this assumption are illustrated in Figure 1. For the convenience of this discussion, the two elastic face layers are called the base and the constraining layers, while the middle viscoelastic one is called the damping layer. The layers are also denoted by numbers 1, 3, and 2, respectively, throughout this study. The displacements u1 and u3 are employed to represent the respective longitudinal displacements of face layers and w denotes the transverse displacement of entire sandwich structure, which is identical for each of the three layers in the Ross, Ungar and Kerwin (RKU) model. Shear deformation in the core layer is determined from the relative motion between u1 and u3. Figure 1.
RKU model displacements for a CLD sandwich beam.

While the assumptions described above are widely used, they are not always valid in certain structures. Rao2 approached the problem using the same transverse displacement assumption as that in Ross et al.1 but with the additional assumption that the longitudinal displacement varies linearly across the thickness of each layer, and the displacement is continuous across the layer interfaces. In that work, all three layers were treated as Timoshenko beams instead of the Euler beams used in the RKU model. Douglas and Yang3,4 examined the effect of compression deformation in the core layer due to the relative transverse displacements of the two face layers. They concluded that damping from the transverse compression deformation of the core layer can be dominant in some cases. Based on this result, Sisemore and Darvennes5 proposed an eighth-order differential equation in terms of the base layer transverse motion. This equation was developed under the assumption that the two face layers only compress the core layer. No other deformations, such as shear, existed in the core layer. In that work, experimental results were compared with the results from the newly developed equation. It was shown that the model could predict the resonant frequencies well. Unfortunately, prediction of the loss factors was not as accurate because the damping from shear deformation was completely neglected. Sylwan6 simultaneously considered the shear and compression damping in a beam. The damping layer was assumed to experience both shear and compressional strain. A set of equations was developed and an iterative scheme used to solve the equations in order to obtain the flexural vibration wavenumbers and loss factors. Based on this previous work, Xie and Shepard7 then developed an enhanced beam analytical model which includes all three types of damping due to extension, shear, and compression. Note that all the research studies mentioned thus far relate to beams as currently there are very few models for CLD in plates. Lee and Kim8 proposed a plate analytical model which included both compression and shear damping. To the authors’ knowledge, though, there are no existing plate analytical models for CLD plates that include all three types of damping.

As a numerical implementation of analytical models, the finite element method (FEM) is widely used in vibration analysis. FEM is often employed in design analysis to facilitate the consideration of numerous designs and allows for the quick exchange of information throughout the various design stages. Several works have considered a FEM implementation for CLD problems. Kosmatka and Liguore9 reviewed the different kinds of FEM elements for CLD, including single-layer and multi-layer, which are illustrated in Figures 2 and 3, respectively. The single-layer element in Figure 2 integrates the degrees of freedom (DOF) for all three layers. Although the basic dynamics of a CLD structure are included, the base, core, and constraining layers are described using one single-layer element. Correspondingly, the multi-layer element shown in Figure 3, in which one element layer is used to represent each layer, looks more like a real structure. Obviously, the multi-layer element has more DOF and thus may require more time in the mesh generation and computation stages. Although the multi-layer element generally produces more precise results, due to the fact that it more closely mimics the actual structure, the increase in model complexity can sometimes be overwhelming. This statement is particularly true when the viscoelstic layer is very thin, as maintaining a reasonable aspect ratio in the core layer elements can produce a very complex model for the remaining structure. Based on the advantages of a single-layer finite element for CLD structures, some specific single-layer FEM models will now be discussed. Figure 2.
Single-layer plate element used to represent a three-layer structure. Figure 3.
Multi-layer solid element used to represent a three-layer structure.

Zapfe and Lesieutre10 presented an element with 11 DOF, which can be considered as the FEM implementation of Rao’s2 model. It is worth noting that Zapfe’s element appears to be more accurate than some of the other element formulations. However, Zapfe’s element does neglect the effect of different transverse displacements in the two face layers. In order to include the effects of compressional damping in these structure models, Xie and Shepard11 developed a new single-layer beam finite element for the CLD beam, which, for the first time, included all three types of damping. Of course, there is currently no single-layer plate finite element for CLD that includes all three types of damping. As a result, there is a need to develop a single-layer plate finite element that includes all three of these types of damping. Such an element would enhance modeling capabilities and enable a more rapid design phase for more realistic systems that include CLD.

As one of the novelties of this study, a single-layer plate finite element is developed to model CLD plates with damping caused by shear, longitudinal extension, as well as transverse compression. This model extends previous research from beam elements to plate elements with the goal that damping in the structure can be more accurately predicted for practical CLD plate analysis. This feature of including all three types of damping overcomes the simplifications used in previous works. It is worth noting that the proposed plate finite element model could conveniently be extended to multi-layer plates with more than three layers. The following section describes the analytical development for this new single-layer finite element. This newly developed finite element model is then validated. Finally, the new model is used to conduct a parametric study on several design parameters, including core layer thickness, face layer thickness, and plate aspect ratio. The latter study is used to illustrate impact of these parameters on a CLD plate’s modal characteristics.

sec.title: Finite element modeling
sec.p: This section describes the assumptions and modeling used to formulate a new plate CLD finite element model. In order that the effects of including compressional damping can be fully investigated, a plate element model that does not include compression damping is also described. Once this model development is complete, a validation and numerical study is presented in the following sections.

sec.title: Assumptions and kinematics relations
sec.p:
Prior to introducing the new plate finite element model, the assumptions used in developing the new plate finite element should be clearly stated:
The transverse displacements of the two face layers w1 and w3 are different.
The longitudinal displacement varies linearly across the thickness of each layer.
There is no slip between connected layers.

The first assumption means that the compression deformation of the core layer resulting from relative transverse displacements of the two face layers is included. The second assumption is the same as that of the Rao’s model in that the effects of both the shear and extension deformations brought by longitudinal displacements of the layers are considered. Based on these assumptions, a new plate finite element can be developed accordingly.

sec.title: New CLD compression plate finite element
sec.p:
With the above assumptions, the displacement vector of the damping layer of the new plate finite element is shown in Figure 4. The displacement vectors for the two face layers are given by (1) and (2) respectively. The corresponding displacement vector for the damping layer is (3) It should be noted that there are 25 DOF for each of two face layers and 30 for the damping layer due to the inclusion of assumption (1) stated earlier. For each DOF listed in the above displacement vectors, the first letter or number in the subscript is the node that this DOF is associated with, whereas the subscript on the vector name denotes the layer number. Figure 4.
Proposed new compression plate finite element.

For the damping layer in the plate finite element, the proposed displacement field, as shown in Figure 4, can be organized as (4) The dimensions of matrix B and F are 3×6 and 6×34, respectively. The B matrix is given as (5) where z and H2 are the transverse coordinate and the thickness of the damping layer, respectively. The F matrix is given by (6)

where ni those for the longitudinal displacements and bi are the shape functions for the transverse displacements. It should be noted that for the two face layers, the B and F matrices are similar to those for the damping layer, but with no additional transverse displacement terms. The shape functions mentioned above are (7) where x and y are the local coordinates within the element, as illustrated in Figure 5. The parameters l1 and l2 are the lengths of the plate in x and y directions, respectively. Figure 5.
Proposed new non-compression plate finite element.

The displacement vector qi of each layer can be assembled into the total displacement vector q for the whole plate finite element as (8) where Gi is the map matrix of the ith layer. TRi is an n×34 matrix where n is the total number of DOF in the plate finite element. For the three-layer case considered here, n = 50. While a CLD plate structure with three layers is employed here as a physical basis for derivation of the motion equations, the approach can be easily extended to CLD structures with more than three layers using the modeling approach given in Zapfe and Lesieutre10.

The element displacement in Equation (4) can be used to calculate the strain as well as the strain energy in the element. The strain and kinetic energies can be written as (9) and (10) respectively, where Ke and Me are the stiffness and mass matrices for the element. Assembling these into the global matrixes K and M can lead to the typical eigenvalue equation (11) Note that the stiffness matrix K in Equation (11) is a complex-valued matrix due to the complex Young’s and shear modulus in the damping layer. Because this newly developed plate finite element includes compression damping, it will be called the compression plate finite element in order to be differentiated from the non-compression plate element to be developed in the following section.

sec.title: Non-compression CLD plate finite element
sec.p: In order to fully examine the effect of compression damping in CLD plates, another single-layer plate finite element which does not include the compression damping effect is also developed by following the similar path for the element developed in the previous section. The non-compression plate finite element is developed by combining the two different transverse displacements of the two face layers, as illustrated in Figure 5. To achieve this, the first assumption in section ‘Assumptions and kinematics relations’ should be changed such that the transverse displacements of all three layers are the same. This modified assumption leads to fewer DOF, with the displacement vector for the ith layer of the non-compression plate finite element being (6) Note that this vector has 25 DOF for each layer, while for the compression plate finite element, there were 34 DOF in the damping layer. As a result of the DOF that are coupled at the interfaces, the compression plate finite element has 50 DOF while the non-compressional one has 41 DOF.

With compressional and non-compressional damped plate finite elements available, it is now possible to investigate the impact of compressional damping in CLD plate structures with different design parameters. Before conducting any further study, though, it is necessary to validate the newly developed plate finite elements.

sec.title: Validation of the new finite element model
sec.p:
With the element formulations given above, it is now necessary to validate the newly developed plate finite elements with and without compressional damping. Wang and Zhao12 conducted modal testing on a CLD plate clamped at all four edges in order to obtain the resonant frequencies and loss factors for the first four modes. The CLD plate tested in Wang and Zhao12 has length 800 mm and width 600 mm. Table 1 provides detailed configuration information of this previously tested CLD plate. Naturally, experimental results in Wang and Zhao12 can be used to validate the new plate finite elements developed in this study. Table 1.
Parameters for the validation from Wang and Zhao12
Parameters Value Parameters Value
Thicknessa 0.00314 m Shear modulusa 25.56 Gpa
Thicknessb 0.00425 m Shear modulusb 1.6 Mpa
Thicknessc 0.00314 m Shear modulusc 25.56 Gpa
Young’s modulusa 68.5 Gpa Densitya 2700 kg/m3
Young’s modulusb 4.768 Mpa Densityb 1100 kg/m3
Young’s modulusc 68.5 Gpa Densityc 2700 kg/m3
Width 0.6 m Length 0.8 m
Loss factor 0.5
Notes: aConstraining layer; bdamping layer; cbase layer.

Based on the configuration information given above, the new compression plate finite element is used to obtain the first four resonant frequencies and loss factors, and then these frequencies and loss factors are compared with experimental results. In the validation, the plate is evenly meshed with 15 nodes on each side which means 14 elements on each side. Table 2 shows that the results from the new plate finite elements are generally very close to the experimental results, especially when predicting the natural frequencies. In addition, as shown in Figures 6 and 7, a convergence study is conducted on the same plate as listed in Table 1. This convergence study checks the variations of the first natural frequency and damping ratio under the increase of number of nodes on each side of the plate. From Figures 6 and 7, it can be seen that results of the first natural frequency and the corresponding damping ratio become converged when there are 13 or more nodes on each side. As a result, it is believed that newly developed plate finite elements are validated and can be used in following parametric studies, and in these parametric studies, plates are also evenly meshed with 15 nodes on each side. It should be noted that the compression and non-compression plate finite elements give similar results here. As discussed below, this similarity simply means that the compression effect is not significant for the configuration listed in Table 2. With the adjustment of various configuration parameters, these two plate finite elements could give different results such that the compression damping effect becomes apparent. To that end, it is necessary to conduct the parametric study in the following section. Table 2.
Comparison between results of new plate finite element models and Wang and Zhao12
Mode Natural frequency (Hz) Damping ratio (%)
New compression FEM New non-compression FEM Wang and Zhao12 New compression FEM New non-compression FEM Wang and Zhao12
1 41 41 41 12.2 12.2 10.4
2 74 74 74 8.9 8.8 8.8
3 97 97 96 7.4 7.4 7.4
4 130 130 126 5.7 5.7 5.9
Figure 6.
Convergence study on the first natural frequency. Figure 7.
Convergence study on the first damping ratio.

sec.title: Parametric studies
sec.p:
In spite of the dominance of shear damping assumed by most previous research, it will be shown below that compression damping can have an important impact on the structure’s dynamic characteristics. This study will consider a CLD plate simply supported at all edges for all three layers with a unit impulse excitation in the middle. Table 3 lists the detailed configuration for this CLD plate. Figure 8 shows a comparison of the frequency response function in the middle of the plate for the transverse DOF w in the non-compression plate finite element and the two transverse DOF, w1 and w3, in the compression plate finite element. It can be seen from the figure that the two face layers have different transverse displacements when the frequency becomes higher, while all these DOF have approximately the same amplitude at frequencies near a resonance. This observation means that damping due to the transverse compression between two face layers cannot be neglected when the excitation frequency is not at a resonance. Of course, when one is only interested in the behavior at resonance, using the simpler model may yield equally valid results with the advantage of less complexity. In addition to examining the impact of neglecting this compressional component, this new compression plate finite element also makes it possible to study the impact of compressional damping with various design parameters. Table 3.
Parameters used in calculating the response and following parametric studies
Parameters Value Parameters Value
Thicknessa 0.006 m Shear modulusa 79.3 GPa
Thicknessb 0.004 m Shear modulusb 1.5 MPa
Thicknessc 0.006 m Shear modulusc 79.3 GPa
Young’s modulusa 200 GPa Densitya 7800 kg/m3
Young’s modulusb 4.768 MPa Densityb 1100 kg/m3
Young’s modulusc 200 GPa Densityc 7800 kg/m3
Width 0.5 m Length 0.5 m
Loss factor 0.5
Notes: aConstraining layer; bdamping layer; cbase layer.
Figure 8.
Comparison of response at the middle of the plate for the two plate finite elements: w for non-compressional FEM, and w1 and w3 for compressional FEM.

In order to examine how different parameters affect the compression damping, comparisons between the compression and non-compression plate finite elements are now conducted under variations of: the core layer thickness, two face layers’ thickness, as well as the plate aspect ratio. The plate is simply supported at all four edges for these comparisons. The sandwich plate used in this portion of the study is 0.5 m long and 0.5 m wide, consisting of two steel face layers. Although the loss factor for a viscoelastic material is generally frequency-dependent, it is conveniently assumed for this simple study to have a constant value of 0.5. Note that this will not be an issue in the future use of this method as the emphasis here is simply to note the difference between the two modeling approaches. This parametric study uses the configuration values listed in Table 3. For the comparison on each selected parameter, all other configuration values are kept constant as shown in Table 3 and the first nine modes of the CLD plate computed and compared.

Tables 4 and 5 show the comparisons between the resonance frequencies and loss factors, respectively, for the two plate finite elements under a variation in thickness of the constraining and base layers. It appears as though the thickness of two face layers does have some impact on the compression damping, at least for the configurations considered here. It can be seen that with higher thicknesses of the two face layers, the frequencies calculated by the two finite elements have significant differences after the 5th mode. It can be noted that for all cases there appears to be a reordering of the natural frequencies when compression of the damping layer is allowed. The behavior is somewhat expected as allowing compressional motion of the middle layer allows for additional cross-sectional modes to occur that are not possible for the non-compressional case. It is clear that further study is needed to find out how exactly these new modes are introduced. This is particularly of interest for cases with higher face layer thicknesses where the greater inertia of the outer layers likely causes such frequencies to be lower and likely well within the region where this study extends. This behavior would also explain the drastic differences in some of the loss factors in Table 5. Again, more in-depth study of the mode shapes is needed to verify this behavior. Table 4.
Comparison of resonant frequencies (Hz) between compression and non-compression plate finite elements under different face layer thicknesses
Modes 1st 2nd 3 rd 4th 5th 6th 7th 8th 9th
Case 1 Compression 103 211 211 211 263 263 390 416 456
0.006 mm Non-compression 103 211 211 211 263 263 416 540 540
Case 2 Compression 120 196 196 196 307 307 368 462 462
0.007 mm Non-compression 120 196 196 196 307 307 484 630 630
Case 3 Compression 137 184 184 184 352 352 353 476 476
0.008 mm Non-compression 137 184 184 184 352 352 553 721 721
Case 4 Compression 164 164 164 172 337 440 440 525 525
0.010 mm Non-compression 164 164 164 172 440 440 689 900 900
Case 5 Compression 150 150 150 206 334 528 528 590 590
0.012 mm Non-compression 150 150 150 206 528 528 825 1079 1079
Note: Unit for resonant frequencies is Hz in all tables.
Table 5.
Comparison of loss factors between compression and non-compression plate finite elements under different face layer thicknesses
Modes 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 5th 6th 7th 8th 9th
Case 1 Compression 0.004 0.500 0.500 0.500 0.001 0.001 0.461 0.001 0.320
0.006 mm Non-compression 0.004 0.500 0.500 0.500 0.001 0.001 0.001 0.001 0.001
Case 2 Compression 0.003 0.500 0.500 0.500 0.001 0.001 0.440 0.265 0.265
0.007 mm Non-compression 0.003 0.500 0.500 0.500 0.001 0.001 0.001 0.001 0.001
Case 3 Compression 0.002 0.500 0.500 0.500 0.001 0.001 0.417 0.212 0.212
0.008 mm Non-compression 0.001 0.500 0.500 0.500 0.001 0.001 0.001 0.001 0.001
Case 4 Compression 0.500 0.500 0.500 0.002 0.360 0.001 0.001 0.140 0.140

0.012 mm Non-compression 0.500 0.500 0.500 0.001 0.001 0.001 0.001 0.001 0.001

Tables 6 and 7 show the comparisons for the resonance frequencies and loss factors, respectively, under the variation in the thickness of the damping layer. It can be seen that both plate finite elements have different resonant frequencies and loss factors in all cases for mode 7 and higher. Furthermore, both plate elements produce the same natural frequency for the first six modes. It can also be noted that for Cases 3–5, the natural frequencies for each model type are the same for the last two modes considered, despite the frequencies for the two models differing from each other. Again, more work is needed to determine what is causing this behavior. It is easy to speculate that the increased damping layer thickness reduces the compressional stiffness of the damping layer, thus reducing the natural frequency of the modes which exhibit compressional (i.e., cross-sectional) behavior. While this behavior is observed in the table, having an exact cause of this needs further work. Clearly, the relatively large loss factor increase shown in Table 7 associated with those differing natural frequencies would indicate that the bulk of the motion for these modes is contained within the damping layer, thus producing a large amount of damping. Still, visualizing the mode shapes would confirm this and will be the subject of future work. Table 6.

Tables 8 and 9 show the comparisons of the resonance frequencies and loss factors, respectively, under variations of plate aspect ratio. In this variation, one side dimension is kept constant while the other side is changed. It can be seen that with higher aspect ratios, the difference shows up in lower order modes than in the previous two comparisons. It seems that due to the variation of the aspect ratio, some higher modes drop in frequency to fall within the range of the first nine modes. For example, similar to the variation of face layers’ thicknesses, all five cases from the compression plate element have the first six modes’ frequencies of the non-compression element in a similar order, while with smaller aspect ratios (Cases 4 and 5), new frequencies (258 Hz for Case 4 and 196 Hz for Case 5) take the place of the 5th mode and push the previous frequencies to higher modes. Also, the variation of aspect ratio only has impact on 2nd, 3rd, and 4th modes so that these three modes should be torsional modes or some other type of mode. Table 8.

From the above comparisons, a conclusion can be drawn that these selected parameters, more or less, have an impact on the contribution of compressional damping. How exactly the modes change due to these parameters needs further study for the compression plate finite element developed in this study. Nevertheless, it is clear that consideration of compressional damping is warranted in some cases while in other cases use of the simpler model that neglects compressional damping has a distinct advantage.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A new compression single-layer plate finite element model for a CLD plate is developed in this study. The displacement field and DOF enable this plate finite element model to capture shear, extension, and compression damping in CLD plates for the first time. This new finite element is validated using experimental results for resonant frequencies and damping ratios from published literature, and then the validated model is employed for a parametric study. The parametric study shows that thicknesses of the damping layer, face layers, and plate aspect ratio all have a potential impact when compression damping is included. However, the exact manner in which the modes change due to the variations of selected parameters needs further study. For some of the cases considered, the inclusion of compressional damping through use of the more complicated model was shown to be unnecessary, thus enabling a more rapid solution approach via implementation of the simpler non-compressional model. The new compression plate finite element model developed provides a generic method for dynamic characteristic investigation of CLD plates. In the future, this finite element model can be used to conduct design optimizations of CLD plates, study how modes change with different parameters, and it also can be used as a starting point for more complicated structures.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

ref.citation: RossDUngarEEKerwinEM. Damping of plate flexural vibrations by means of viscoelastic laminae. New York: ASME Annual Meeting Structural Damping, 195949–88.
RaoDK. Vibration of short sandwich beams. J Sound Vib 1977; 52(2): 253–263.
DouglasBEYangJCS. Transverse compressional damping in the vibratory response of elastic-viscoelastic-elastic beams. AIAA J 1978; 16(9): 925–930.
DouglasBE. Compressional damping in three-layer beams incorporating nearly incompressible viscoelastic cores. J Sound Vib 1986; 104(2): 343–347.
SisemoreCLDarvennesCL. Transverse vibration of elastic-viscoelastic-elastic sandwich beams: compression-experimental and analytical study. J Sound Vib 2002; 252(1): 155–167.
